questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Type I

Defect: perforated tympanic membrane.

Repaired using a graft. (myringoplasty) (Option A ruled out)

Type II

Defect: Eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane.

Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus. (Option B ruled out)

Type III

Defect: Absence of malleus and incus.

Graft placed directly on stapes head (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of melena that contains gastric mucosa and acute intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following structure was found, what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Definition

Congenital true diverticulum of the small intestine, resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.

Rule of 2’s

2% population, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2 inches in length, 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric, pancreatic), 2 years most common presentation, 2:1 male predominance.

Clinical Features

Painless bleeding (melena), intestinal obstruction, diverticulitis, volvulus, intussusception.

Diagnosis

Meckel’s scan (Tc-99m pertechnetate scan for ectopic gastric mucosa).

Treatment

Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental resection) if symptomatic.

questions.text: Scientists administered norepinephrine to guinea pigs, resulting in an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and a decrease in heart rate. What mechanism explains this response?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation:
First Degree AV Block

Pathology
  • First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) without disruption of conduction from atria to ventricles.
  • The delay typically occurs in the AV node, but may also involve the atria, His bundle, or Purkinje fibers.

Etiology
  • Commonly attributed to increased vagal tone in younger patients.
  • In older patients, often due to fibrotic changes in the cardiac conduction system.
  • Other causes include coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, electrolyte abnormalities, inflammation, infections, certain drugs, infiltrative diseases, collagen vascular diseases, and idiopathic degenerative diseases.
  • Lymes disease, Chagas disease, Diphtheria, Rheumatoid arthritis, Scleroderma.

Clinical Features
  • Usually asymptomatic; patients are often unaware of the condition until discovered on an ECG.
  • In cases where the PR interval exceeds 0.30 seconds, symptoms may resemble "pacemaker syndrome," including dyspnea, malaise, lightheadedness, and chest pain.

ECG Features
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds on an ECG.
  • PR interval can be marked (>0.30 seconds) in some cases, and P waves may appear within preceding T waves.

Treatment
  • Generally, no treatment is required; routine observation is sufficient.
  • Pacemaker placement may be considered for symptomatic patients with PR interval >0.30 seconds or those with coexisting heart disease.
  • No antiarrhythmic medications are indicated, and surveillance with routine ECGs is recommended to monitor for worsening.

questions.text: This instrument is contraindicated for?
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

Piper forceps

  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births
  • It has distinct perineal curve, allows for application to the aftercoming head in breech delivery. (Option C)

Simpson forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

Wrigley's forceps

 
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

Kielland forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions. (Option D)
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

questions.text: Which of the following is the classical triad of acute cholangitis?
questions.explanation:
Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

questions.text: Which of the following is the culture media used for tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Enriched Media

Name

Characteristics

Image

Blood agar

Base medium enriched with 5-10% defibrinated sheep blood, used to grow moderately fastidious bacteria and observe hemolytic reactions.


 

Chocolate agar

This is an enriched medium made by heating blood agar, which lyses red blood cells and releases nutrients such as haemoglobin and NAD. It supports the growth of fastidious bacteria such as Haemophilus and Neisseria species.

Brain-heart infusion (BHI) broth

This is an enriched medium containing nutrients from brains and beef hearts, along with peptones, glucose, sodium chloride, and buffers. It supports the growth of non-fastidious and moderately fastidious microorganisms.

serum slope

An enriched medium with high serum content, prepared with eggs. Primarily used for the recovery and identification of Corynebacterium diphtheriae from nose and throat specimens.

Lowenstein-Jensen medium: Used specifically for cultivating Mycobacterium species, this enriched, selective medium contains glycerol, mineral salts, aspargine, malachite green, and hen’s eggs.

questions.text: Identify the fracture:
questions.explanation:
Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture

(Option D)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

 

Comminuted fracture

 

Gutter fracture

Ring Fracture

 

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option C)

 

 
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

 

Ring fracture

 

 

Hinge fracture

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

(Option B)

 

 

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

 

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Diastatic Fracture

questions.explanation:
Stab wound/Punctured wound

These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width.

Weapons used

  • Knife (most common)
  • Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle)
  • Scissors
  • Screwdrivers
  • Pens
  • Ice picks
  • Forks

Types of stab wounds

  • Puncture wound: (Option C)
    • Soft tissues are involved
  • Penetrating wound:
    • Enters a body cavity or a viscus
  • Perforating wound:
    • Through-and-through puncture wounds
    • The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other
    • The wound of entry is larger than the exit

Significance of the wound dimensions

  • Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin.
  • Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping.
  • Depth, the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation.
  • Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising.
    • Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges
    • If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed

A patient presents with lower symmetric flaccidity and no cord reflex, suggesting which condition?
questions.explanation:
Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS)

Category

Symptoms

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
    • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
    • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
    • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
    • Difficulty in climbing stairs
    • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

questions.explanation:
Metabolism of Acetaminophen
  • Acetaminophen is mainly metabolized via phase II reactions into harmless sulfate and glucuronide metabolites.
  • A small portion undergoes phase I metabolism by CYP2E1, forming the hepatotoxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI).

Detoxification of NAPQI

  • NAPQI is neutralized by binding to glutathione, forming water-soluble mercapturic acid, which is excreted via the kidneys.

Glutathione Depletion

  • When excessive NAPQI is produced, or glutathione is depleted, NAPQI binds to hepatocyte macromolecules, forming acetaminophen-protein adducts, causing hepatocyte necrosis.

Risk Factors
  • Chronic alcohol use (induces CYP2E1, depletes glutathione).
  • Starvation.
  • Prior use of mixed-function oxidase-inducing drugs (e.g., phenobarbital, INH).
  • Hepatitis C infection increases the risk of liver injury in overdose.

Clinical features

Early Symptoms (4-12 hrs):

  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, shock.

Delayed Symptoms (24-48 hrs):

  • Hepatic injury becomes apparent.
  • Coagulopathy and encephalopathy.
  • Maximal damage seen 3–5 days post-ingestion with aminotransferase levels >10,000 IU/L.
  • Renal failure and myocardial injury may occur.

Stages of acute acetaminophen poisoning

Stage

Time Post-Ingestion

Description

I

0–24 hours

Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.

II

24–72 hours

Right upper quadrant abdominal pain; elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), and sometimes increased bilirubin and INR if poisoning is severe.

III

72–96 hours

Vomiting, signs of liver failure; peak levels of AST, ALT, bilirubin, and INR. Possible renal failure and pancreatitis.

IV

> 5 days

Recovery of liver function or progression to multiple organ failure.

Diagnostic Method

Description

Specific Features for Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Sample Collection

Collect specimens such as sputum, urine, wound swabs, blood, ear discharge, eye discharge, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Specimens vary based on the site of infection.

Gram stain

Forms uniform turbidity with surface pellicle.

Selective medium that inhibits other Gram-negative bacteria; specifically selected for Pseudomonas aeruginosa; pigment production (e.g., pyocyanin).

used to increase pigment production by pseudomonas

Positive

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), 16S rRNA sequencing

Provides specific and sensitive detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa DNA.

Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing

Disk diffusion method, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) testing

Determines the susceptibility of Pseudomonas aeruginosa to various antibiotics.

Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS)

    • Parkinson's - Occurs within days to weeks
    • Akathisia - Occurs within days to weeks (Option C)

questions.text: OCPs are not protective for?
questions.explanation:
Cancer Type

Effect of COC Use

Key Findings

Endometrial Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by ≥30%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for years after discontinuation.
  • More pronounced reduction seen in smokers, obese women, and those with low physical activity.

Ovarian Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 30–50%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for 10–15 years after stopping, even with short-term use (≥6 months).
  • Protection extends to BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation carriers.

Colorectal Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 15–20%.

Breast Cancer

Increased Risk
  • COC use increases risk by 25%, especially in nulliparous women who start before age 24 and use it for >4 years.
  • If breast cancer develops, it is usually well-differentiated with a good prognosis.
  • The increased risk disappears after 10 years of stopping.

Cervical Cancer

Increased Risk
  • Prolonged COC use increases risk, particularly of adenocarcinoma of the cervix.
  • Women using COCs for ≥5 years have a higher risk, with risk increasing with longer duration.

A 23 year old male epileptic patient presented with pain in right shoulder region. Examination revealed that right upper limb was abducted and externally rotated and the movements could not be performed. Which of the following is most likely diagnosed
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Anterior dislocation

Posterior dislocation

(Option D)

Inferior dislocation

(Option B)

Frequency

Most common

Not very common

Rare

Mechanism of Injury

Fall on an outstretched hand with an abducted and externally rotated shoulder.

Occurs during seizures or convulsions.

  • A fall onto a flexed, adducted arm.
  • A direct impact to the anterior aspect of the shoulder.
  • A fall onto an outstretched hand.
  • Also called luxatio erecta.
  • Result from a severe hyper-abduction force.

Clinical presentation

Pain, swelling and movement restriction.

Tests

Duga’s test, Hamilton ruler test and Regimental badge test.

Callaway’s test and Regimental badge test

Bryant’s test

Arm Position

Abduction and external rotation

Adduction and internal rotation

Arm locked in hyperabduction with the hand positioned above the head.

X-ray Findings
  • The humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position).
  • "Hill-Sachs lesion" (compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head).

 
  • The humeral head is displaced posteriorly, appearing closer to the scapula.
  • ‘Light bulb sign’(humeral head appears rounded due to internal rotation).
  • ‘Rim sign’ (widening of the glenohumeral joint space).
  • ‘Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion’ (compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head).

 

The humeral head is displaced inferiorly below the glenoid cavity.

 

Management

Reduction techniques:

  • Kocher's method (Most commonly used)
  • Hippocrates method
  • Stimson’s technique

Reduction and immobility, followed by active exercises.


 
  • Closed reduction
  • Open reduction if soft tissue injuries are present
  • Re-examination after reduction to avoid neurovascular injuries.

Complications
  • Early:
    • Neurovascular injuries
    • Rotator cuff tear
  • Delayed:
    • Recurrence
    • Stiffness
    • Unreduced dislocation
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation
  • Neurovascular injuries
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation

Anterior Shoulder dislocation

Subtypes
  • Subglenoid: The humeral head lies below the glenoid fossa.
  • Subclavicular: The humeral head is displaced beneath the clavicle.
  • Intrathoracic: The humeral head dislocates into the thoracic cavity, which is rare.
  • Subcoracoid: The humeral head lies below the coracoid process.

Clinical findings
  • Loss of the deltoid contour (loss of shoulder roundness)
  • The shoulder is extended, abducted and externally rotated.

Clinical tests
  • Duga’s test is the inability to touch the opposite shoulder.
  • Hamilton ruler test is where the gap between the ruler and the arm is lost.
  • Callaway’s test is increased girth of the axilla on the dislocated side.
  • Bryant’s Test is where the anterior axillary fold is displaced downward on the affected side.
  • Regiment batch sign is loss of sensation due to axillary nerve damage.

Imaging
  • X-ray reveals that the humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position)
  • An MRI is necessary to assess soft-tissue injuries and identify Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions, which are complications of shoulder dislocations and increase the risk of recurrence due to joint instability.

Management
  • Kocher's method (Most common method) is the reduction by traction, external rotation, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • In Hippocrates' method, the surgeon pulls the semi-abducted arm firmly while using his foot in the axilla as a fulcrum to reduce the dislocation.
  • Stimson’s technique is the reduction by applying weight for traction, using the body as counter traction.

questions.text: A woman had a difficult labour. She complains of dribbling of urine 7 days after surgery. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cystoscopy with dye test
  • It involves inserting a dye solution (methylene blue) to confirm the diagnosis.

MRI or CT Scan
  • These imaging modalities may be used to assess complex cases or to plan surgical repair, providing detailed anatomical information.

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP)
  • (IVP) is a diagnostic imaging test that is not typically used as a primary method to diagnose vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF).

Conservative

Surgical
  • Genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • In 10 per cent of cases, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small.




 

Transvaginal Repair:

  • This approach involves accessing the fistula through the vaginal wall.
  • It is suitable for smaller fistulas and those located in favourable positions that allow for direct access and closure.

Transabdominal Repair:

  • Larger or more complex fistulas may require an abdominal approach.
  • This can be done via laparotomy (open surgery) or laparoscopy (minimally invasive surgery).
  • Laparoscopy is preferred when feasible as it offers faster recovery and reduced postoperative complications.

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1%. What is the most probable diagnosis?
A baby is born with microcephaly, intracerebral calcification and chorioretinitis. Which teratogenic infections is the mother suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Etiology

Primary maternal infection with Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy is the primary cause

Risk Factors

Infection during the first trimester: severe outcomes, lower transmission rate (~17%)

Infection during third trimester: milder outcomes, higher transmission rate (~65%)

Clinical Features

CNS: Hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, seizures, developmental delays, microcephaly in severe brain damage

Ocular: Chorioretinitis, vision impairment, strabismus, photophobia, epiphora

Systemic: Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, prematurity

Other: Jaundice, thrombocytopenia, rash, hearing loss

Diagnosis Method

Details

Fetal Ultrasound

Performed every 2 weeks during gestation after diagnosis of maternal infection.

PCR Analysis of Amniotic Fluid

Used for prenatal diagnosis of fetal infection.

Serologic Tests

Persistent or rising titers in dye/IFA tests, positive IgM-ELISA.

Newborn Evaluation

General, ophthalmologic, and neurologic exams; head CT scan for intracranial calcifications.

CSF Analysis

Lumbar puncture with analysis for Toxoplasma-specific IgG and IgM, total IgG, cells, glucose, and protein.

Toxoplasma Isolation

Isolation from placenta, infant’s leukocytes, and CSF using PCR

Treatment

Details

Pyrimethamine and Sulfadiazine, along with Folinic Acid (Calcium Leucovorin)

Synergistic action against Toxoplasma gondii. Standard treatment for congenital toxoplasmosis. Folinic Acid is administered to prevent bone marrow suppression caused by pyrimethamine

Spiramycin

Used in pregnant women during the first trimester to prevent vertical transmission.

Monitoring

Regular leukocyte counts twice weekly to detect neutropenia and other hematologic effects.

What type of fracture is caused by a hammer?
questions.explanation:
Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

 

Depressed fracture

 

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture

Ring Fracture

(Option D)

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option C)
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.



 

Ring fracture

 

Hinge fracture

Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

(Option A)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

 

Narrow fissure skull fracture

 

Diastatic Fracture

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate was brought to the hospital with a complaint of non-bilious vomiting. While examining the baby, the physician noted a lump in the left epigastric region, which showed movement while feeding. What is the likely diagnosis of this child?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

Genetic Factors
  • White race of northern European descent
  • Male sex
  • Familial History: Higher risk in offspring of mothers with CHPS (20% for sons, 10% for daughters)
  • Twin Studies: Higher concordance in monozygotic twins suggests a genetic component
  • Blood Groups: Infants with B and O blood groups.

Environmental Factors
  • Erythromycin Use: Especially if administered within the first two weeks of life
  • Higher incidence in infants whose mothers used macrolides during pregnancy or breastfeeding, particularly in females.

Other Associated Factors
  • Other Congenital Defects Syndromes: Occasionally associated with tracheoesophageal fistula and hypoplasia or agenesis of the inferior labial frenulum.
  • Associated with eosinophilic gastroenteritis, Apert syndrome, Zellweger syndrome, trisomy 18, Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome, and Cornelia de Lange syndrome.

Characteristic findings of Contrast studies in CHPS

Findings

Description

String Sign

A thin line of contrast material passes through the narrowed pyloric channel, indicating severe narrowing due to hypertrophied muscle.

Shoulder Sign

A bulge of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle into the gastric antrum gives the appearance of a “shoulder.”

Double Tract Sign

Parallel streaks of contrast material within the narrowed pyloric channel suggest the presence of a narrow passage for contrast flow.

Mushroom sign

Bulging of the hypertrophic muscle into the 1st part of the duodenum.

Moderately underweight

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height-for-age is < -3 SDs.

questions.text: Identify the defect in the given image:
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Definition

Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly.

Inheritance

Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance.

Maternal risk factors

Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency.

Types of NTDs

Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly.

Spina bifida occulta

Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence.

Craniorachischisis

Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus.

Meningocele

Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering.

Myelomeningocele

Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation.

Anencephaly

Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore.

Iniencephaly

Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect.

Prenatal diagnosis

Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).

Prevention

0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child).

Risk of recurrence

3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children.

Treatment

Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present.

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.explanation:
Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention

Causes

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.

Pathophysiological Process

Classic Triad of Symptoms
  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)

CSF Findings
  • Opening pressure: Elevated
  • Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs)
  • Protein: Elevated
  • Glucose: Decreased
  • Gross appearance: Turbid

Treatment
  • Immediate Management:
    • Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone
    • Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Criteria

Details

Diagnostic Criteria for SAM

Assessment for Complications

Check for the following complications:

  • Severe edema (+++)
  • Low appetite (fails appetite test)
  • Medical complications
  • Presence of one or more danger signs (as per IMNCI guidelines)

Management Approach

Based on the presence or absence of complications:

  • If NO complications → Uncomplicated SAM → Supervised home management
  • If YES (complications present) → Complicated SAM → Inpatient management in a healthcare facility

A disease with mitochondrial inheritance is inherited from which family member?
questions.explanation:
Inheritance Pattern
  • Maternal inheritance: All children of an affected female inherit the disease.
  • Homoplasmy: Presence of mtDNA which is either all wild type or all mutated.
  • Heteroplasmy: Presence of both wild type (normal) and mutated mtDNA in the same individual.
  • Threshold effect: Minimum percentage of mutated mtDNA required for disease manifestation. In the presence of heteroplasmy, the threshold effect leads to variability in clinical expression across different tissues and mtDNA mutations.

Examples (Mnemonic: KLMNOP)
  1. Kearns-Sayre syndrome- Pigmentary retinopathy, cerebellar ataxia, heart block
  2. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy- Subacute painless bilateral visual failure
  3. MELAS- Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy, Lactic acidosis, Stroke-like episodes
  4. MERRF- Myoclonic epilepsy, Seizures, Ataxia
  5. NARP- Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis pigmentosa
  6. CPEO- Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia, Bilateral Ptosis
  7. Pearson syndrome- Sideroblastic anemia of childhood, pancytopenia, pancreatic involvement

questions.text: Patient with HIV presenting with bouts of cough and fever. Which medium is appropriate for diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
    • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
    • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
    • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
    • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
    • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
    • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: A patient presents with the palsy of the face as shown. Which of the following is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of facial nerve is involved.
  • Males and females are equally affected.

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir (Adult doses)
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not reversed with the administration of atropine?

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade

questions.correct_answer: B. Muscle weakness due to neuromuscular blockade
questions.explanation:
Atropine

Classification
  • Anticholinergic drug (Muscarinic receptor antagonist)
  • Competitive antagonist at muscarinic receptors

Mechanism of Action
  • Competitive inhibition of postganglionic acetylcholine muscarinic receptors
  • Blocks all subtypes of muscarinic receptors (M₁, M₂, M₃)
  • Direct vagolytic action leading to parasympathetic inhibition
  • Allows preexisting sympathetic stimulation to predominate

Pharmacological Actions

1. CNS Effects
  • Overall CNS stimulant action
  • Stimulates medullary centers (vagal, respiratory, vasomotor)
  • Depresses vestibular excitation (antimotion sickness property)
  • Suppresses tremor and rigidity in parkinsonism
  • High doses: cortical excitation, restlessness, hallucinations, delirium
  • Very high doses: respiratory depression and coma

2. CVS

Heart:

  • Tachycardia (primary effect) - blocks M₂ receptors on SA node (Option A Ruled Out)
  • Initial transient bradycardia may occur with IM/SC injection
  • Abbreviates refractory period of A-V node
  • Facilitates A-V conduction
  • Shortens P-R interval
 

Blood Pressure:

  • No consistent/marked effect on BP
  • Tachycardia and vasomotor center stimulation tend to raise BP
  • Histamine release and direct vasodilator action (at high doses) tend to lower BP
  • Blocks vasodepressor action of cholinergic agonists

3. Eye
  • Mydriasis (pupil dilation)
  • Cycloplegia (paralysis of accommodation)
  • Abolition of light reflex
  • Effects last 7-10 days with topical application
  • May increase intraocular tension, especially in narrow angle glaucoma
  • Has mild local anesthetic action on cornea

4. Smooth Muscles
  • Relaxes all visceral smooth muscles with parasympathetic innervation (M₃ blockade)
  • Reduces tone and amplitude of GI contractions
  • Slows passage of chyme; may cause constipation
  • Causes bronchodilation, reduces airway resistance (Option D Ruled Out)
  • Relaxes ureter and urinary bladder
  • Relaxation of biliary tract (less marked)
  • Minimal effect on uterus

5. Glandular Secretions
  • Markedly decreases sweat, salivary, tracheobronchial and lacrimal secretions (M₃ blockade) (Option C Ruled Out)

6. Body Temperature
  • Higher doses can cause rise in body temperature
  • Due to inhibition of sweating and stimulation of temperature regulating center
  • Children are highly susceptible to atropine fever

Relative Sensitivity of Organs

Decreasing order of sensitivity:

Saliva, sweat, bronchial secretion > eye, bronchial muscle, heart > smooth muscle of intestine, bladder > gastric glands and smooth muscle

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.correct_answer: B. LMWH followed by oral anticoagulant
questions.explanation:
Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning

Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins.

  • Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein
  • Absence of compressibility
  • Absence of blood flow

Venogram

Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness.

Impedance Plethysmography

Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis.

Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays

Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer.

D-dimer has a high negative predictive value.

Radioactive Fibrinogen Study

Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used.

Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI)

Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC.

Initial Anticoagulation
  • Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases.
  • Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment.
  • Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Transition to Oral Anticoagulation
  • Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence.
  • Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor).
  • Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs).

Monitoring Anticoagulation
  • Heparin: Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT).
  • Warfarin: INR maintained between 2.0 to 3.0.

For Patients with contraindications to Anticoagulation

Temporary IVC Filter: Consider if bleeding risk prevents anticoagulation or to prevent pulmonary embolism. It does not treat the existing thrombus and is associated with long-term complications. (Option D)

Endovascular Surgery
  • Thrombus removal, lysis, and stenting.
  • Beneficial in selected patients, especially those with iliofemoral thrombosis, to reduce risk of chronic post-thrombotic syndrome.

A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Details


 

Food Poisoning
  • Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic.
  • Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion.
  • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare)
  • Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-6 hours.
  • Some cases may include diarrhoea

Other Infections
  • Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis
  • More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients

Diagnostic Method

Details

Food Poisoning
  • Culture of implicated food essential.
  • >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis.
  • Quantitative stool cultures with at least 105 cells per gram support diagnosis.

Culture Characteristics
  • Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar.
  • β-hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance.
  • Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin

Selective Media
  • MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources

Microscopy
  • Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli.
  • Motile

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child presents with fever, rash, and Bitot spots. What is the appropriate line of management?
questions.explanation:
Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature)
 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.
 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is taking indomethacin and an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. What potential side effect is likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Drug Interaction

Mechanism

Clinical Implication

ACE Inhibitors + Potassium Supplements/K-sparing diuretics

Risk of hyperkalemia due to reduced aldosterone secretion by ACE inhibitors combined with potassium-retaining agents.

Monitoring serum potassium levels is crucial to avoid hyperkalemia, which can cause serious cardiac issues such as arrhythmias.

ACE Inhibitors + NSAIDs

NSAIDs can reduce the anti-hypertensive effects of ACE inhibitors and decrease renal blood flow, increasing the risk of acute renal failure (ARF) or oliguria.

Use caution when combining NSAIDs with ACE inhibitors, and closely monitor renal function, particularly in high-risk patients.

ACE Inhibitors + Lithium

ACE inhibitors can increase the reabsorption of lithium, potentially leading to lithium toxicity.

Monitor lithium levels carefully when starting or adjusting ACE inhibitors in patients taking lithium, and adjust the lithium dosage as needed.

ACE Inhibitors + Antacids

Reduced bioavailability of ACE inhibitors due to binding with antacids.

Administer ACE inhibitors at least two hours before or after antacids to maintain their efficacy.

ACE Inhibitors + Diuretics

Diuretics enhance the hypotensive effects of ACE inhibitors by depleting sodium and raising renin levels.

In patients already on diuretics, start ACE inhibitors at a low dose to minimise the risk of excessive blood pressure reduction initially.

questions.text: A 30-year-old met with a bike accident and presented with the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

 

Mechanism of injury:
 

Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.
